photo.title: Cathedral and Baptistry

photo.description: Baptistry of St. John (Battistero di San Giovanni), Pisa, Italy On entering the baptistery, the immensity of the building is even more convincing than from outside. Here, in fact, we obtain an immediate sense of the proportions. The is 55 mts and the diameter 35.50 mts: bare values, but from inside, at this moments, the height and and amplitude have another meaning, so penetrating as to cause admiration and dismay. We are, in fact, under the huge vault of the dome and in front of a grandiose annular nave discreetly lighted by the numerous windows distributed all around. Our attentions will be very soon drawn by the Font and the Pulpit. The Font is located in the middle of the temple on three steps. It's a work of GUIDO BIGARELLI.
photo.tags: pisa italy tuscany baptistry stjohn
photo.title: Baptistry of St. John (Battistero di San Giovanni), Pisa, Italy

photo.description: This man did a really cool demonstration of the echoes in the baptistery. He changed the pitch of his voice up and down to make it sound like one person was a whole choir singing in harmony as the echoes rang throughout the building.

On entering the baptistery, the immensity of the building is even more convincing than from outside. Here, in fact, we obtain an immediate sense of the proportions. The is 55 mts and the diameter 35.50 mts: bare values, but from inside, at this moments, the height and and amplitude have another meaning, so penetrating as to cause admiration and dismay. We are, in fact, under the huge vault of the dome and in front of a grandiose annular nave discreetly lighted by the numerous windows distributed all around. Our attentions will be very soon drawn by the Font and the Pulpit. The Font is located in the middle of the temple on three steps. It's a work of GUIDO BIGARELLI.

photo.title: Baptistry of St. John

photo.description: Baptistry of St John (Battistero di San Giovanni). It is the largest baptistry in Italy, begun in the 12th Century and completed in the 14th. It does, in fact, lean slightly. The building bridges the gaps between Romaneque style (rounded windows below) to Gothic (pointed window openings higher up).
